February 6, 2011: Fiction
SHADOWFEVER, by Karen Marie Moning. (Delacorte, $26.) Hunting for her
sister’s murderer, MacKayla Lane is caught up in the struggle between humans
and the Fae.
STRATEGIC MOVES, by Stuart Woods. (Putnam, $25.95.) In the 19th Stone
Barrington novel, the New York lawyer works with the C.I.A. to transport a fugitive.
THE GIRL WHO KICKED THE HORNET’S NEST, by Stieg Larsson. (Knopf,
$27.95.) The third volume of a trilogy about a Swedish hacker and a journalist.
THE INNER CIRCLE, by Brad Meltzer. (Grand Central, $26.99.) An archivist
discovers a book that once belonged to George Washington and conceals a
deadly secret.
THE SENTRY, by Robert Crais. (Putnam, $26.95.) Joe Pike and Elvis Cole,
Hollywood private eyes, try to help a woman who is not as innocent as she
appears.
CALL ME IRRESISTIBLE, by Susan Elizabeth Phillips. (William
Morrow/HarperCollins, $25.99.) In a small town in Texas, characters from
Phillips’s earlier novels reappear as a woman persuades a friend to call off her
wedding to the town’s popular mayor.
DEAD OR ALIVE, by Tom Clancy with Grant Blackwood. (Putnam, $28.95.)
Familiar Clancy characters appear as an intelligence group tracks a vicious
terrorist called the Emir.
THE HELP, by Kathryn Stockett. (Amy Einhorn/Putnam, $24.95.) A young white
woman and two black maids in 1960s Mississippi.
THE CONFESSION, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $28.95.) A criminal wants to
save an innocent man on death row, but he must convince the authorities he’s
telling the truth.
WHAT THE NIGHT KNOWS, by Dean Koontz. (Bantam, $28.) Someone is
murdering entire families, recreating in detail a crime spree that took place two
decades earlier.
ROOM, by Emma Donoghue. (Little, Brown, $24.99.) A mother’s prison is her
young son’s entire world.
CROSS FIRE, by James Patterson. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Alex Cross
investigates a professional assassination in Washington, and receives a chilling
call from a deadly adversary.
FREEDOM, by Jonathan Franzen. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $28.) A family of
Midwestern liberals during the Bush years.
February 6, 2011
Non-Fiction
UNBROKEN, by Laura Hillenbrand. (Random House, $27.) An Olympic runner’s
story of survival as a prisoner of the Japanese in World War II.
BATTLE HYMN OF THE TIGER MOTHER, by Amy Chua. (Penguin Press,
$25.95.) A Chinese-American mother makes a case for strict and demanding
parenting.
DECISION POINTS, by George W. Bush. (Crown, $35.) The former president’s
memoir discusses his Christianity and the end of his drinking; his relationships
with members of his family; and his decisions on 9/11, Iraq and Katrina.
AUTOBIOGRAPHY OF MARK TWAIN, VOL. 1, by Mark Twain. (University of
California, $34.95.) In his autobiography, published unexpurgated for the first time,
Twain is pointedly political and willing to play the angry prophet.
CLEOPATRA, by Stacy Schiff. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The last queen of ancient
Egypt was ambitious, audacious and formidably intelligent.
LIFE, by Keith Richards with James Fox. (Little, Brown, $29.99.) The Rolling
Stones guitarist’s revealing autobiography is also a portrait of the era when rock ’n’
roll came of age.
THE IMMORTAL LIFE OF HENRIETTA LACKS, by Rebecca Skloot. (Crown,
$26.) The story of a woman whose cancer cells were cultured without her
permission in 1951.
DECODED, by Jay-Z. (Spiegel & Grau, $35.) The hip-hop star leads a narrative
journey through his lyrics and his life.
THE LONGEST WAR, by Peter L. Bergen. (Free Press, $28.) An overview of the
conflict between the United States and Al Qaeda illuminates the miscalculations
on both sides.
OUTLIERS, by Malcolm Gladwell. (Little, Brown, $27.99.) Why some people
succeed — it has to do with luck and opportunity — from the author of “Blink.”
ASSHOLES FINISH FIRST, by Tucker Max. (Gallery, $25.99.) Stories of bad
decisions, debauchery and sexual recklessness.
SH*T MY DAD SAYS, by Justin Halpern. (It Books/HarperCollins, $15.99.) A
memoir organized around the musings, purveyed on Twitter, of the author’s father.
MY FATHER AT 100, by Ron Reagan. (Viking, $25.95.) Reagan recalls his “warm
yet remote” and “fundamentally inscrutable” father, a century after his birth.
EARTH (THE BOOK), by Jon Stewart, David Javerbaum, Rory Albanese, Steve
Bodow and Josh Lieb. (Grand Central, $27.99.) A visitor’s guide to the human
